74. Just as Herodianus has written,
his topmost half is naked, and in order to depict
some concealment/mystery,
his very long hair and beard hang down below.
On his body and legs sit, as if playing,
sixteen children, as tall as an arm
from hand to elbow;
the explanation comes from Philostratus.

75. Describing the Image of the God,
he considers these children,
how the Nile flows in such manner
that it floods over Egypt,
high over the edges of its banks
to sixteen elbows or Cubits,
thus these sixteen Children are signs
that the Nile floods reach such a number.

76. It happened once a year at a certain time,
but is the number is four Cubits less
the people of Egypt are not happy,
for on both banks they are expecting
the burden of a period of higher prices
during the following Year.
Thus the sixteenth of the Children
was depicted sitting high upon his Cornucopia
as this was the measure of a fruitful Year.

77. Along his right arm he rests
the horn of plenty, rich with fruit,
with his left arm leaning on a beast
which many have incorrectly thought to be a Sphinx,
being like a Lion behind, and a maiden in front;
but it means that this earthly
occurs in the land when the course of the Sun
has reached Leo and Virgo.
left-middleThe Sphinx is not depicted without Bird's wings and is a Dog, from behind, with a Dragon's tail.

78. Around the edge of the base are depicted
various crops which are found in the morasses:
reeds, papyrus, trees, Colocasium,
and various Animals who eat them,
such as hippopotami who splash about in that water,
with horsesâ€™ backs and long manes,
and with tails and teeth like wild boars,
blunt snouts, and cloven hoofs like Oxen.
left-middlePliny, Book 5. chap. 9. and Book 18. chap. 18.

79. Then also Indian rats, Ibises, and Skinks,
and above them, those small misshapen dwarves,
Tentyrites from the Egyptian Provinces,
Who like brave princes with their tiny ships
So torment and annoy the Crocodiles
That they must give way and hide themselves
before these celebrated lionhearted Heroes.
